snippet: Communities on Long Island, in Alabama and in North Carolina recently gathered to say tearful goodbyes to players. But football continues to thrive.
abstract: Juliet Macur Sports Of The Times column observes that deaths of three high school football players within a single week, along with rash of scandals in the NFL, have failed to cause broad public reevaluation of the sport; questions what it will take before Americans walk away from their televisions on game days.

byline.contributor: Mary Pilon contributed reporting from Wading River, N.Y.

lead_paragraph: Communities on Long Island, in Alabama and in North Carolina recently gathered to say tearful goodbyes to players. But football continues to thrive.

headline.main: Burying Young Players Isn’t Part of the Game
headline.print_headline: Burying Young Players Isn’t Part of the Game
